Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: (base) By ordinance / thurgh out the Citee large
(base) Hanged with clooth of gold / and noght with sarge
(base) ¶ Ful lyk a lord / this noble duc gan ryde
(base) Thise two Thebans / vpon eyther syde
(base) And after rood the queene / and Emelye
(base) And after that another compaignye
(base) Of oon and oother / after hir degree
(base) And after hem of comunes aft̉er/re here degre
(base) And thus they passen / thurgh out the Citee
(base) And to the lystes / coome they bityme
(base) It nas nat of the day / yet fully pryme
(base) ¶ Whan set was Theseus / ful ryche and hye
(base) Ypolita the queene / and Emelye
(base) And othere ladyes / in degrees aboute
(base) Vnto the setes / preeseth al the route
(base) And westward / thurgh the gates vnder Marte
(base) Arcite / and eek the hundred of his parte
(base) With baner reed / is entred right anon
(base) ¶ And in that selue moment Palamoun
(base) Is vnder Venus Estward in the place
(base) With baner whit / and hardy cheere and face
(base) In al the world / to seken vp and down
(base) So euene / withouten variacioun
(base) Ther nere / swiche compaignyes tweye
(base) For ther was noon so wys / that koude seye
(base) That any hadde / of oother auantage
(base) Of worthynesse / ne of estaat ne age
(base) So euene were they chosen for to gesse
(base) And in two renges / faire they hem dresse
(base) ¶ Whan that hir names / rad were euerichon
(base) That in hir nombre / gyle were ther noon
(base) Tho were the gates shet and cryd was loude
(base) Do now youre deuoir / yonge knyghtes proude
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ The heraudes / lefte hir prikyng vp and down
(base) Now ryngen trompes loude / and Clarioun
(base) Ther is namoore to seyn / but West and Est
(base) In goon the speres / ful sadly in the arest
(base) In gooth the sharpe spore / in to the syde
(base) Ther seen men / who kan Iuste / and who kan ryde
(base) Ther shyueren shaftes / vpon sheeldes thikke
(base) He feeleth / thurgh the herte spoon the prykke
(base) Vp spryngeth speres / twenty foot on highte
(base) Out goon the swerdes / as the siluer brighte
(base) The helmes they tohewen / and to shrede
(base) Out brest the blood / with sterne stremys rede
(base) With myghty maces / the bones they tobreste
(base) He thurgh the thikkest of the throng gan threste
(base) Ther stomblen steedes stronge / and doun gooth al
(base) He rolleth vnder foot as dooth a bal
(base) He foyneth on his feet with his tronchoun
(base) And he hym hurteth / with his hors adoun
(base) He thurgh the body is hurt and sithen ytake
(base) Maugree his heed / and broght vnto the stake
(base) As forward was / right there he moste abyde
(base) Another / lad is on that oother syde
(base) ¶ And som tyme / dooth hem Theseus to reste
(base) Hem to refresshe / and drynken if hem leste
(base) Ful ofte a day / haue thise Thebans two
(base) Togydre ymet and wroght his felawe wo
(base) Vnhorsed hath ech oother / of hem tweye
(base) Ther nas no tygre / in the vale of Galgopheye
(base) Whan that hir whelp is stole / whan it is lyte
(base) So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
(base) For Ialous herte / vpon this Palamon
(base) Ne in Belmarye / ther nys so fel leoun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That hunted is / or for his hunger wood
(base) Ne of his praye / desireth so the blood
(base) As Palamon / to sleen his foo Arcite
(base) The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes byte
(base) Out renneth blood / on bothe hir sydes rede
(base) ¶ Som tyme an ende ther is / of euery dede
(base) For er the sonne / vnto the reste wente
(base) The stronge kyng Emetrius / gan hente
(base) This Palamon / as he faught with Arcite
(base) And made his swerd / depe in his flessh to byte
(base) And by the force of twenty / is he take
(base) Vnyolden / and ydrawen to the stake
(base) And in the rescous / of this Palamoun
(base) The stronge kyng lygurge / is born adoun
(base) And kyng Emetrius / for al his strengthe
(base) Is born out of his Sadel / a swerdes lengthe
(base) So hitte hym Palamon / er he were take
(base) But al for noght he was broght to the stake
(base) His hardy herte / myghte hym helpe naught
(base) He moste abyde / whan that he was caught
(base) By force / and eek by composicioun
(base) ¶ Who sorweth now / but woful Palamoun
(base) That moot namoore / goon agayn to fighte
(base) And whan that Theseus / hadde seen this sighte
(base) Vnto the folk / that foghten thus echon
(base) Ne non schal lenger to his felaw gon
(base) He cryde / hoo namoore / for it is doon
(base) I wol be trewe Iuge / and nat partye
(base) Arcite of Thebes / shal haue Emelye
(base) That by his fortune / hath hire faire ywonne
(base) Anon ther is a noyse of peple bigonne
(base) For ioye of this / so loude and heigh with alle
(base) It semed / that the lystes sholde falle
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ What kan now faire Venus / doon aboue
(base) What seith she now / what dooth this queene of loue
(base) But wepeth so / for wantyng of hir wille
(base) Til that hir teerys / in the lystes fille
(base) She seyde / I am ashamed doutelees
(base) ¶ Saturnus seyde / doghter hoold thy pees
(base) Mars hath his wyl / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And by myn heed / thow shalt been esed soone
(base) ¶ The trompours / with the loude Mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that ful loude yelle and crye
(base) Been in hir wele / for ioye of daun Arcite
(base) But herkneth me / and stynteth noyse alite
(base) Which a myracle / ther bifel anon
(base) ¶ This fierse Arcite / hath of his helm ydon
(base) And on a Courser / for to shewe his face
(base) He priketh / endelong the large place
(base) Lookyng vpward / vpon this Emelye
(base) And she agayn / hym caste a freendly eye
(base) For wymen as speketh the comune
(base) Þay folwe alle þe fauour of fortune
(base) And she was al his cheere / as in his herte
(base) They folowe the fauour of Fortune
(base) Out of the ground / a furye Infernal sterte
(base) From Pluto sent / at requeste of Saturne
(base) For which his hors / for feere gan to turne
(base) And leep asyde / and foundred as he leep
(base) And er that Arcite / may taken keep
(base) He pighte hym / on the pomel of his heed
(base) That in the place / he lay as he were deed
(base) His brest to brosten / with his Sadel bowe
(base) As blak he lay / as any col / or crowe
(base) So was the blood / yronnen in his face
(base) Anon he was yborn out of the place
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) With herte soor / to Theseus Paleys
(base) Tho was he coruen / out of his harneys
(base) And in a bed ybroght ful faire and blyue
(base) For he was yet in memorie and alyue
(base) And alwey cryinge / after Emelye
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his compaignye
(base) Is comen hoom / to Atthenes his Citee
(base) With alle blisse / and greet solempnytee
(base) Al be it that this auenture was falle
(base) He nolde noght disconforten hem alle
(base) ¶ Men seyde eek Arcite / shal nat dye
(base) He shal been heelyd / of his maladye
(base) And of another thyng they were as fayn
(base) That of hem alle / was ther noon yslayn
(base) Al were they soore yhurt and namely oon
(base) That with a Spere / was thirled the brest boon
(base) ¶ To oothere woundes / and to broken armes
(base) Somme hadden salues / and somme hadden charmes
(base) Some hadde saluys made for the nones
(base) Fermacyes of herbes / and eek saue
(base) They dronken / for they wolde hir lymes haue
(base) For which this noble duc / as he wel kan
(base) Conforteth / and honoureth euery man
(base) And made reuel / al the longe nyght
(base) Vnto the straunge lordes / as was right
(base) ¶ Ne ther was holden / no disconfitynge
(base) But as a Iustes / or a tourneyinge
(base) For soothly / ther was no disconfiture
(base) For fallyng. nys nat but an auenture
(base) Ne to been had by force / vnto the stake
(base) Vnyolden / and with twenty knyghtes take
(base) O persone allone / withouten mo
(base) And haryed forth / by arm / foot / and to
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And eek his steede / dryuen forth with staues
(base) With footmen / bothe yemen and eek knaues
(base) It nas arretted hym / no vileynye
(base) Ther may no man / clepe it cowardye
(base) ¶ For which anoon / duc Theseus leet crye
(base) To stynten / al rancour and enuye
(base) The gre / as wel of oo syde as of oother
(base) And eyther syde ylyk as otheres brother
(base) And yaf hem yiftes / after hir degree
(base) And fully heeld a feeste / dayes three
(base) And conueyed / the kynges worthily
(base) Out of his toun / a iournee largely
(base) And hoom wente euery man / the righte way
(base) Ther was namoore / but fare wel haue good day
(base) Of this bataille / I wol namoore endite
(base) But speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) Of Palamon wil I stynte alite
(base) ¶ Explicit secunda pars
(base) ¶ Incipit pars tercia and vltīma
(base) Swelleth the brest of Arcite / and the soore
(base) Encreeseth at his herte / moore and moore
(base) The clothered blood / for any lechecraft
(base) Corrupteth / and is in his bouk / ylaft
(base) That neyther veyne blood / ne ventusynge
(base) Ne drynke of herbes / may been his helpynge
(base) The vertu expulsyf / or animal
(base) Fro thilke vertu / clepyd natural
(base) Ne may the venym / voyden ne expelle
(base) The pipes of his longes / gan to swelle
(base) And euery lacerte / in his brest adown
(base) Is shent with venym and corrupcioun
(base) Hym gayneth neither / for to gete his lyf
(base) Vomyt vpward / ne downward laxatyf
(base) Al is to brosten / thilke regioun
(base) Nature / hath no dominacioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And certeinly / ther nature wol nat werche
(base) Fare wel Phisyk. go ber the man to cherche
(base) This al and som / that Arcita moot dye
(base) For which / he sendeth after Emelye
(base) And Palamon / that was his cosyn deere
(base) Thanne seyde he thus / as ye shal after heere
(base) ¶ Nat may the woful spirit in myn herte
(base) Declare a point of alle my sorwes smerte
(base) To yow my lady / that I loue moost
(base) But I byquethe / the seruice of my goost
(base) To yow / abouen euery creature
(base) Syn that my lyf / may no lenger dure
(base) Allas the wo / allas the peynes stronge
(base) That I for yow haue suffred / and so longe
(base) Allas the deeth / allas myn Emelye
(base) Allas / departyng of oure compaignye
(base) Allas myn hertes queene / allas my wif
(base) Myn hertes lady / endere of my lyf
(base) Myn hertys lady cawser of my tene
(base) What is this world / what axeth men to haue
(base) Now with his loue / now in his colde graue
(base) Allone / with outen any compaignye
(base) Fare wel / my sweete foo / myn Emelye
(base) And softe taak me / in youre Armes tweye
(base) For loue of god / and herkneth what I seye
(base) ¶ I haue heer / with my cosyn Palamoun
(base) Had stryf and rancour / many a day goun
(base) For loue of yow / and for my Ialousye
(base) And Iuppiter / so wys my soule gye
(base) To speken / of a seruaunt proprely
(base) With circumstaunces alle / trewely
(base) That is to seyn / trouthe / honour / knyghthede
(base) Wisdom / humblesse / estaat / and heigh kynrede
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Fredom / and al / that longeth to that art
(base) So Iuppiter / haue of my soule part
(base) As in this world / right now ne knowe I non
(base) So worthy to been loued / as Palamon
(base) That serueth yow / and wol doon al his lyf
(base) And if that euere / ye shal been a wyf
(base) Foryet nat Palamon / the gentil man
(base) And with that word / his speche faille gan
(base) For from his feet vp to his brest was come
(base) The coold of deeth / that hadde hym ouercome
(base) And yet moore ouer / for in his armes two
(base) The vital strengthe / is lost and al ago
(base) Oonly the Intellect withoute moore
(base) That dwelled in his herte / syk and soore
(base) Gan faillen / whan the herte felte deeth
(base) Dusked hise eyen two / and fayled breeth
(base) But on his lady / yet caste he his eye
(base) His laste word / was mercy Emelye
(base) His spirit chaunged hous / and wente ther
(base) As I cam neuere / I kan nat tellen wher
(base) Therfore I stynte / I nam no dyuynystre
(base) Of soules / fynde I nat in this Registre
(base) Ne me ne lyst / thilke opynyons to telle
(base) Of hem / thogh that they writen wher they dwelle
(base) Arcite is coold / ther Mars his soule gye
(base) Now wol I speken / forth of Emelye
(base) That soroweth and cryeth I wyl not lye
(base) Now wepith Emelye ⁊and waylith Palamon
(base) ¶ Shrighte Emelye / and howleth Palamon
(base) And Theseus / his suster took anon
(base) Swownynge / and baar hire fro the corps away
(base) What helpeth it to tarien forth the day
(base) To tellen how she weep / bothe eue and morwe
(base) For in swich caas / wommen haue swich sorwe
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Whan that hir housbondes / been from hem ago
(base) That for the moore part they sorwen so
(base) Or ellis fallen / in swich a maladye
(base) That at the laste / certeinly they dye
(base) ¶ Infinite / been the sorwes and the teerys
(base) Of olde folk. and folk of tendre yeerys
(base) In al the town / for the deeth of this Theban
(base) As þat þ̉er/re was for deþ of þis Theban
(base) For hym ther wepeth bothe child a man
(base) For sorwe of him þer weepeþ boþe child and man
(base) So greet wepyng was ther noon certayn
(base) Whan Ector was broght al fressh yslayn
(base) To Troye / allas the pitee that was ther
(base) Cracchynge of chekes / rentyng eek of heer
(base) Why woldest thow be deed / thise wommen crye
(base) And haddest gold ynow / and Emelye
(base) ¶ No man / myghte gladen Theseus
(base) Sauyng his olde fader Egeus
(base) That knew / this worldes transmutacioun
(base) As he hadde seyn it chaungen / bothe vp and down
(base) Ioye after wo / and wo after gladnesse
(base) And shewed hem / ensample and lyknesse
(base) ¶ Right as ther deyed neuere man / quod he
(base) That he ne lyued in erthe / in som degree
(base) Right so / ther lyued neuere man he seyde
(base) In al this world / that som tyme he ne deyde
(base) This world / nys but a thurghfare / ful of wo
(base) And we been pilgrymes / passynge to and fro
(base) Deeth is an ende / of euery worldly soore
(base) And oueral this / yet seyde he muchel moore
(base) To this effect ful wysly / to enhorte
(base) The peple / that they sholde hem reconforte
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his bisy cure
(base) Caste now / wher that the sepulture
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Of goode Arcite / may best ymaked be
(base) And eek moost honurable / in his degree
(base) And at the laste / he took conclusioun
(base) That ther / as first Arcite and Palamoun
(base) Hadden for loue / the bataille hem bitwene
(base) That in the selue groue / swoote and grene
(base) Ther as he hadde / hise amorouse desires
(base) His compleinte / and for loue his hote fyres
(base) He wolde make a fyr / in which the office
(base) Funeral / he myghte al acomplice
(base) And leet anoon comaunde / to hakke and hewe
(base) The okes olde / and leyen hem on a rewe
(base) In colpons / wel arrayed for to brenne
(base) Hise officers / with swifte feet they renne
(base) And ryde anoon / at his comandement
(base) And after this / Theseus hath ysent
(base) After a Beere / and it al ouerspradde
(base) With clooth of gold / the richeste / that he hadde
(base) And of the same suyte / he cladde Arcite
(base) Vpon his handes / his gloues white
(base) Eek on his heed / a coroune of laurer greene
(base) And in his hand / a swerd ful bright and keene
(base) He leyde hym bare the visage / on the beere
(base) Ther with he weep / that pitee was to heere
(base) And for the peple / sholde seen hym alle
(base) Whan it was day / he broghte hym to the halle
(base) That roreth / of the cryyng and the sown
(base) Tho cam / this woful Theban Palamoun
(base) With flotry berd / and ruggy asshy heerys
(base) In clothes blake / ydropped al with teerys
(base) And passyng othere / of wepyng Emelye
(base) The rufulleste / of al the compaignye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In as muche / as the seruyce sholde be
(base) The moore noble / and ryche in his degree
(base) Duc Theseus / leet forth thre steedes brynge
(base) ¶ Duke theseus anon with oute lette
(base) Thre stedis white hath comaundid sette
(base) Vpon the whiche stedes trapped welle
(base) With cloth of golde ouer maile of stel
(base) That trapped weren in steel al gliterynge
(base) And couered with the armes / of daun Arcite
(base) Vpon thise steedes / grete and whyte
(base) Ther seten folk / of which oon baar his sheeld
(base) Another his spere / vpon his hondes heeld
(base) The thridde bar with hym / his bowe Turkeys
(base) Of brend gold / was the caas / and eek the harneys
(base) And ryden forth a paas / with sorweful cheere
(base) Toward the groue / as ye shul after heere
(base) The nobleste of the Grekys / that ther were
(base) Vpon hir shuldres / carieden the beere
(base) With slak paas / and eyen rede and weete
(base) Thurgh out the Citee / by the maister streete
(base) That sprad was al with blak and wonder hye
(base) Right of the same / is the strete ywrye
(base) Vpon the right hand / wente olde Egeus
(base) And on that oother syde / duc Theseus
(base) With vessels in hir hand / of gold ful fyn
(base) Al ful of hony / melk / and blood and wyn
(base) Eek Palamon / with ful greet compaignye
(base) And after that / cam woful Emelye
(base) With fyr in hande / as was that tyme the gyse
(base) To do the office / of funeral seruyse
(base) ¶ Heigh labour / and greet apparaillynge
(base) Was at the seruyce / and the fyr makynge
(base) That with his grene top / the heuene raughte
(base) And twenty fadme of brede / the armes straughte
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) This is to seyn / the bowes / were so brode
(base) Of stree first ther was leyd many a lode
(base) But how the fyr was maked vpon highte
(base) Ne eek the names / how the trees highte
(base) As ook / Fyrre / Birch / Asp / Alder / holm / popler
(base) Wylow / Elm / Plane / Assh / Box / Chestayn / lynde / laurer
(base) Wilow / elme / plane hasil and whipultre
(base) Mapul / Thorn / Beech / hasyl / Ew / whippultree
(base) Mapil thorn / bech / aspe / box chesteyn lynd / laurer
(base) How they were feld / shal nat been told for me
(base) Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and doun
(base) Desherited / of hir habitacioun
(base) In which they woneden / in reste and pees
(base) Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrides
(base) Ne how the beestes / and the bryddes alle
(base) Fledden / for fered / whan the wode was falle
(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
(base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree
(base) And thanne with drye stikkes / clouen a three
(base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
(base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thryes wᵗith here sperys claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale

div.l: Here endeth the knyghtes tale Here bigynneth the Millers tale
When the knyght his tale had tolde
In al company was ther yong ne olde .
That he ne sayde hit was a noble story
And worthi to ben drawen in memory .
And namely the gentilnesse of euerychon
Oure ost lough ⁊and swere bi seint Iohn
This goth a right vnbokeled is the male
Somwhat to quyte wᵗith the knightes tale .
For treuly the game is wel bigonne
Now telle ye sir monk if ye conne .
Som what to quyte wᵗith the monkes tale
¶ The Myller sat for dronke al pale .
So that vnnethe vpon his hors he sat
Ne nought a valed hood ne hat .
Ne abideth no man for his curtesye
But in pilates voys he bi gan to crye .
And swor bi armes blod ⁊and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones .
Wᵗith the whiche I wol quyte the knight his tale
Oure ost say he was dronken of ale .
And seide abyde Robyn dere brother
Som better man shal telle furst a nother .
And seide a byde ⁊and let vis wirke thryftily
¶ Bi godes soule qd he that wol not I .
For I wol speke or elles go my wey
Oure ost seyde on a deuell wey .
Thou art a fole thi wit is ouer come
¶ Now herkeneth qd the myller all ⁊and some .
But furst I make a protestacioıı̄un
That I am dronken I wot wel bi my soıı̄un . ¶
And ther fore if I mys speke or say
Wyte that ale at southwerk I you pray .
For I wol telle a legende of a lyf
Of a carpynter ⁊and of his wyf
How that a clerk sette a carpynteres cap
¶ The Reue onswerede ⁊and sayde stynt thi clap
Let be thi lewde ⁊and dronken harlotry
Hit is a synne ⁊and eke a gret vilany .
And eke to brynge wyues in such a blame
For sone may a woman haue a euel name .
Thou maist y nough of other thynges sayn
¶ This dronken myller spak ful sone a gayn .
And seyde leue brother Oswolde
Whoso hath no wyf is no cokewolde .
But I sei not ther fore that thou art on
Ther beth full gode wyues mony on .
Whi art thou angry wᵗith my tale now
I haue a wyf ꝑper/parde as wel as thow .
Yit wolde I not for the oxen in my plough
Taken vpon me more than y nough .
As demen of my self that I were on
I bi leue that I ne am on .
And husbond shal not been Inquysityf
Of godes pryuyte ne of his wyf .
So he may fynde godes foysen there
Of the remenaunt nedeth not to enquere .
¶ What shulde I sey but that this myller
He wolde his wordes for no man for ber .
But tolde his churles termes on this manere
Me thynketh that I shal reherce hit here .
And ther fore euery gentil wight I pray
Demes not for godes loue I say . ¶
For euel entent for I mot reherce
Hur tales ben ther better or wers .
Or elles falsen som of my matere .
And ther fore whos lesteneth not to here .
Turne ouer the lef ⁊and chese a nother tale
For ye shull fynde y nowe both gret ⁊and smale .
Of storiall thing that towcheth gentilnesse
And eke moralite and holynesse .
Blatheth not me thaugh ye chesen a mys
The myller is a clerk ye knowe wel thys .
So was the reue eke ⁊and other mo
And harlatry thei tolden bothe two .
Auyseth you ⁊and putteth me out of blame
And eke men shulde not make ernest of game .
SOm tyme ther was dwellyng at Oxenforde
A ryche gnof that gystes hulde to borde .
And of his craft he was a carpentere
Wᵗith him dwellyng was a pore scolere .
Had lerned art but al his fantasye
Was turned to lerne Astrologye .
And couthe a certayne of conclusyons
To demen bi Interrogacyons .
If that men asken in certayne howres
When shulde be drougthe ⁊and when showres .
Or if that men asken him what shal bi falle
Of euery thing I may not rekene alle .
¶ This clerk was cleped hende Nicolas
For of derne loue he couthe ⁊and solas .
And ther to he was wel slye ⁊and pryue
A lyke a mayde meke forto se .
A chambur he had in that ostrye ¶
Alone wᵗith oute eny companye .
Ful fetesly dight wᵗith herbes sote
And he him self as swete as is the rote .
Of lycorys or of eny sedewale
His almagyst ⁊and his bokes gret ⁊and smale .
His asterlabour longyng for his art
His sanguyne stones liggyng feyre a part .
On shelues liggyng at his beddes hed
His presse couered wᵗith a faldyng red .
And al a boue lay a gay sawtrye
On whiche he made a night melodye .
So sweteli that al the chambre rong
And Angelus ad virginēm he song .
And after that he song the kynges note
Ful ofte blessed was his mery throte .
And thus the swete clerk his tyme spent
After his frendes fyndyng ⁊and his rent .
This carpynter had wedded a newe wyf
Whiche that he louede more than his lyf
Of .xviij. þer sheo was of age
Ielouse he was ⁊and huld hir narowe in cage .
For sheo was yong ⁊and wylde ⁊and he was olde
And demed him self to ben a cokewolde .
He knewe not catoıı̄un for his wit is rude
That bad men shulde wedde hur symylitude .
Men shulde wedde after hur estate
For youthe ⁊and elde beth ofte at debate .
But sethen he was fallen in the snare
He most endure as other folk his care .
¶ Fayre was the yong wyf ⁊and ther wᵗith al
As any vessell hir body gentell ⁊and smal .
A seynt sheo wered barred al wᵗith selke ¶
A barmecloth whyte as morowe mylk
Vpon hur lendes sat full mony a gore
White was hur smok ⁊and browded al bi fore .
And eke bihynde at hur coler aboute
Of colblak selk wᵗith ynne ⁊and wᵗith owte .
The tappes of hur white voliper
Were of the same sewte of hur coler .
Hur fylet brod selk ⁊and set ful hye
And sikerli sheo had a lykerows eye .
Ful smale y pulled were hur browes
And tho were bent ⁊and blake as eny sloes .
Sheo was more blessfull for to se
Than is the newe pere genet tre .
And softer then is the wolle of the wether
And bi hur bosom ther hyng a purs of lether .
Tarselled wᵗith selk ⁊and perled wᵗith latoıı̄un
In al this world to seke vp ⁊and doıı̄un .
Ther was no man so wys that couthe thenche
So gay a popelote or such a wenche .
Ful bright was the shynyng of hur hewe
That in the tour the noble forged newe .
¶ But of hur song sheo was so lowde ⁊and yerne
As eny swalowe sittyng on a berne .
Therto sheo couthe skyppe ⁊and make a game
As eny kide or calf folowyng the dame .
Hur mouth was swetter than bragot or meth
Or hord of Appeles in heye or heth .
Wynsyng sheo was as is a Iolyf colt
Long as a mast ⁊and vpright as a bolt .
A broche sheo bar on hur loue coler
As brod as the bos of a bokeler .
Hur shoes were laced on legges hye ¶
Sheo was a prymyrole a pygges eye .
For eny lord to leggen in his bedde
Or yet for eny good yoman to wedde .
¶ Now sire ⁊and after bi fell this cas
That on a day this hende Nicolas .
Fel wᵗith this yong wyf to rage ⁊and playe
While hur husbonde was at Oseneye .
As clerkes ben ful sotell ⁊and full queynte
And pⁱriuely he caught hur bi the queynte .
And seide ywis but if I haue my wille
For loue of the lemman I spille .
And huld hur harde bi the hanche bones
And seide lemman loue me wel at ones .
Or I wol deyen so god me saue
And sheo sprang as a cok doth in the trame .
And wᵗith hur hed sheo wryeth faste away
Sheo seyde I wil not kysse the bi my fay .
Whi qd sheo let be Nicolas
Or I wol crye out ⁊and alas .
Do wey your hondes for your curtesy .
¶ Yit mercy can hende Nicolas cry .
And spak so fayre ⁊and ꝓprofured him so fast
That sheo hur loue graunted him at the last .
And swore bi seint Thomas in kent
That sheo wolde be at his comaundement .
When sheo hur leyser may best a spye
Myn husbonde is full of Ielousye .
That but ye wayte wel ⁊and ben pryue
I wot wel I am but ded qd she .
Ye most be full derne as in this cas
¶ Nay therfore care I not qd Nicolas .
A clerk hath lightly bi set his wyle ¶
But I couthe a carpynter bi gyle .
And thus thei acorded were ⁊and wer sworn
To wayten a tyme as I tolde bi forn .
¶ When Nicolas had do this euerydell
And thacked hur aboute the lendes well
He cusseth hur swete ⁊and taketh his sawtry
And pleyeth faste ⁊and maketh melody .
¶ Then fell hit thus that to the paryssh churche
Cristes owne werkes for to worche .
This good wyf wente vp on an holyday
Hur forehed shone as bright as eny day .
So was hit wasshen whan sheo laft hur werk
¶ Now was ther of that paryssh church a clerk .
The whiche was cleped Absolon
Crulled was his her ⁊and as the gold shon .
And strowted as fanne large ⁊and brod
Ful euen ⁊and streght lay his Iolyshod .
His rode was rede his eyen grey as a goos
Wᵗith poules wyndowes coruen in his shoos .
In hoses rede he wente fetusly
Y clothed he was full smale ⁊and ꝓpropurly .
And in curtell of light waget
Ful feyre ⁊and thicke were the poyntes set .
And there vpon he had a gay surplys
As white as is the blode of the rys .
A mery child he was so god me saue
Wel couthe he lete blod or knytte or shaue .
And make a chartur of lond ⁊and acquytaunce
¶ In twenty maner couthe he tryppe ⁊and daunce .
After the scole of Oxenforde tho
And wᵗith his legges caste to ⁊and fro .
And pleyen songes vpon a smale rybibe ¶
And therto he song somtyme a lowde quynybe .
And as well couthe he pleye on a geterne
In al the town nas brewe hous ne tauerne .
That he ne visyted hit wᵗith his solas
Ther as eny gaylard tapster was .
But soth to sey he was somdel skoymes
Of fartyng ⁊and of speche daungeres .
¶ This absolon that Ioly is ⁊and gay
Goth wᵗith the sensure on the holi day .
Sensyng the wyues ⁊and the parish faste
And mony a louely lok on hur he caste .
And namely on this carpynteres wyf
To loke on hur him thought a mery lyf .
Sheo was so ꝓpropur so sote ⁊and so lykerows
I dar wel sey if sheo had ben a mows .
And he a cat he wolde hur hent a non
¶ This parissh clerk this Ioly Absolon .
Hath in his herte such a loue longyng
That of no wyf took he non offeryng .
For curtesye he seide he wolde non
The mone when hit was night bright shon .
And absolon his geterne hath y take
For paramoures thought he for to wake
And forth he goth Ioly ⁊and amerows
Til he cam to the carpynteres hows .
A litell after the cockes had y crowe
And he dressed him vp bi a shot wyndowe .
That was vpon the carpynteres wall
He syngeth in his voys gentell ⁊and small
Now dere lady if thi wille be
I pray that ye thenke on me .
Ful well accordyng to his geternyng ¶
This carpynter a wok ⁊and harde him synge .
And spak vn to his wyf ⁊and sayde a non
What alysoıı̄un herest thou not absyloıı̄un .
That chaunteth thus vnder oure boures all
And sheo onswered hur husbonde ther wᵗith all .
Yis god wot Iohn I here hit euery dell
¶ This passeth forth what woll ye better than well
Fro day to day this Ioly Absolon
So seweth hur that he is wo bygon .
He waketh al the night ⁊and al the day
He kembeth his lockes brode ⁊and maketh him gay .
He woweth bi menes ⁊and bi brocage
And swore he wolde ben hur owne page .
He syngeth brockyng as eny nyghtyngale
He sente hur meth pyment ⁊and spiced ale .
And wafres pypyng hot out of the glede
And for sheo was of town he ꝓprofured hur mede .
For som folk woll wynne women wᵗith rychesse
Som for strokes som for gentilesse .
¶ Som tyme to shewe lightnesse ⁊and maystrye
He pleyed heroude vpon a scaffold hye .
But what auayled him in this cas
Sheo loueth so this hende Nicolas .
That Absolon may blowe at the buckeshorn
He ne hath for his labour but a skorn .
And thus sheo maketh Absolon hur ape
And al his ernest is turned to a Iape .
For sothe this ꝓprouerbe hit is no lye
Men seyen alwey the nigh slye .
Maketh the fer loue to be loth
For thaugh that Absolon be wod or wroth .
Bi cause he was fer fro hur sight ¶
This nyght Nicolas stode in his light .
Now bere the well hende Nicolas
For Absolon may weyle ⁊and synge alas .
And so bifell that on a setterday
This carpynter was gon to Osenay .
And hende Nicolas and Alysoıı̄un
Accorded beth to this conclusyoıı̄un .
That Nicolas shal shapen him a wyle
This sely ⁊and Ielows husbonde to bigyle .
And if so be this game wente a right
Sheo shulde slepe in his armes al night .
For this was his desyr ⁊and hures also
And right a non wᵗith oute wordes mo .
This Nicolas no lenger wolde tary
But doth ful softe to his chambur cary .
Bothe mete ⁊and drynke for a day or twey
Whiles the carpynter was at Oseney .
And euer he bad bi eny wey
That to hur husbonde sheo shulde sey .
That if he axed after Nicolas
Sheo shulde sey sheo nyst where he was .
Of al that day sheo say him not eye
Sheo trowed sheo sayde in maladye .
For no cry that hur mayde couthe him calle
He nolde onswere for no thyng that might bifalle .
¶ This passeth forth al thilke setterday
That Nicolas stylle in his chambur lay .
And ete ⁊and slept ⁊and dude what him lust
Til sonneday that the sonne goth to rest .
¶ This sely carpynter hath gret meruayle
Of Nicolas ⁊and what thing might him ayle .
And sayde I am a drad bi seynt Thomas ¶
That hit stont not a right wᵗith Nicolas .
God shilde that he dye sodenly
This world is ful tekell sycurly .
I say a cors to day boren to churche
That now a monday last I say him worche .
Go vp qd he vn to his knaue a non
Clepe at his dore ⁊and knocke wᵗith a ston .
Loke how hit is ⁊and telle me boldely
¶ The knaue goth vp ful sturdely .
And at the chambur while he stod
He cryed ⁊and knocked as he were wod .
What how what mayster Nicolay
How may ye slepe al the long day .
¶ But al for nought he herd not a word
An hole he fond ful a lough vpon a bord .
Ther as the cat was wont in to crepe
And at the hole he loked in full depe .
And at the laste he hedde of him a sight
This Nicolas sat euer gapyng vpright .
As he had loked on the newe mone
A doıı̄un he goth ⁊and tolde his maister sone .
In what a ray he say this ilke man
¶ This carpynter to blesse him bi gan .
And seyde helpe vs seynt Frideswide
A mon wot litell what him shal bitide .
mon is fallen wᵗith astronomye
In som wodnesse or in som agonye .
I thought as well how hit shulde be
Men shulde not knowe of goddes pryuete .
Ye blessed be alwey a lewde man
That nought only but his bileue can .
So ferde a nother clerk wᵗith his astronomye ¶
He walked in to the feldes for to prye .
Vpon the sterres what ther shulde bi falle
Til he was in amarle pyt falle .
He say not well but yit bi seynt Thomas
Me reweth sore for hende Nicolas .
He shal ben arated out of his studying
If that I may bi heuene kyng .
¶ Gete me a staf that I may vnder spere
Whiles that thou robyn heuest vp the dore .
And to the chambur dore he can him dresse
He shall out of his studying as I gesse .
His knaue was a strong cherl for the nones
And bi the haspe he lyft vp at ones .
Into the flore the dore ran doıı̄un anon
This Nicolas ay sat stylle as eny ston .
And euer gaped vpward in to the eyre
This carpynter wende he were in dispeyre .
And hente him bi the shuldres mightily
And shoke him harde ⁊and cryed spytously
What howe Nicolay loke a doıı̄un
Awak ⁊and thenk on cristes passioıı̄un .
I croyce the fro the euel ⁊and fro the wightes
Ther wᵗith the night spelle seide he a non rightes .
Of foure halues of the hows a boute
And on the therssholde on the dore wᵗith oute .
Ihc cryst and seynt benedight
Blesse this hows from euery wicked wight .
For the night mare the white Pater nr
Where went thou seynt petres suster .
And at the last this hende Nicholas
Bygan forto syke sore ⁊and seyde alas
Shall all the worlde be lost efte sone nowe ¶
This carpynter onswerede ⁊and seyde what seist thou .
Thenke on god as we men that doıı̄un swynke
Nicolas onswered facche me drynke .
After shall I speke in pryuete
Thyng that toucheth bothe the ⁊and me .
But tell non other in certeyne
The carpynter goth doıı̄un ⁊and cometh a geyne .
And brought of mighti ale a large quart
And when that ilke man had dronke his part .
This Nicolas his dore faste shit
And doıı̄un the carpynter bi him he set .
¶ And seide Iohn ofte lef and dere
Thou shalt vpon thi trouthe swer here .
That to no wight thou shalt this coıı̄unseil wrye
For hit is crystes counseil that I seye .
For if thou bi wrye me tho shalt be wod
¶ Nay cryst forbede for his holy blod .
Qd this sely man I am no blabbe
Ne if I sey hit I am not lef to gabbe .
Sey what thou wolt I shall hit neuer telle
To wyf ne child bi him that harowed helle .
¶ Now Iohn qd this Nicolas I wol not lye
I haue founde in myne Astrologye .
As I haue loked in the mone bright
That now a monday next at quarter night .
Shal falle a reyne ⁊and that so wylde ⁊and wod
That half so greet was neuer Noe flod .
This world he seyde in lasse then an hour
Shal al be dreynt so hydowes is the shour .
That shal mankynde drenche ⁊and lesen hur lyf
¶ This carpyter onsweirde alas my wyf .
And shal sheo drenche alas myn Alisoıı̄un ¶
For sorowe of this almost he fell a doıı̄un .
And seyde is ther no remedye in this cas
Whi yes for gode qd hende Nicolas .
If thou wilt worche after counseil or rede
Thou mayst not worche after thyn owne hede .
For thus seyde Salamon that was ful trewe
Wyrke al bi counseil ⁊and thou shalt not rewe .
And if thou wirke wel bi good counseile
I vnder take wᵗith oute mast or seile .
Yit shall I saue hur the ⁊and me
Hast thou not herd how saued was Noe .
When oure lord had warned him bi forn
That al the world wᵗith water shulde be lorn .
¶ Yis qd this carpynter ful yore a go
¶ Hast not herd qd Nicolas also
The sorowe of Noe wᵗith his felesshipe
Er he might gete his wyf to the shipe .
Him had be leuer I vnder take
At all tyme then all his wetheres blake .
That sheo had a ship alone
And ther fore wost what is best to done .
This asketh haste ⁊and of an hasty thyng
Men may not preche ne make tarying .
¶ A non go gete vs faste in to this Inne
A knedyng trough or elles a kemelynne .
For ilke of vs on but loke that thei ben large
In whiche men may swymme as in a barge .
An haue ther Inne vitayle sufficient
But for oo day fy on the remenent .
The water shal a slake ⁊and gon his way
A boute pryme of the nexte day .
But Robyn may not wite this thy knaue ¶
Ne eke Gille thi mayde I may not saue .
Axe not whi for theigh thou axe me
I wol not telle goddes pryuete .
Hit suffiseth the but if thi wittes mad
To haue as gret a grace as euer Noe had .
Thi wyf shal I wel saue wᵗith oute doute
Go now thi way ⁊and spede here a boute .
¶ But when thou hast for the ⁊and hur ⁊and me
Geten vs knedyng tubbes thre .
Then shalt thou honge hem in the rof ful hye
That no man of oure purpos a spye .
And hast oure vitayle feyre y leyd
And when thou hast thus doıı̄un as I haue seyd .
And eke an ax to smyte the corde a to
When that the water cometh that we may go .
And breken an hole an high vpon a gable
Vn to gardeyn ward ouer the stable .
That we may frely passe forth oure way
When that the shour is passed a way .
Then shalt thou swymme as mery I vndertake
As doth the white doge after the drake .
Then wol I clepe how Alisoıı̄un how Iohn
Be mery for the flod wol passe a non .
And thou wolt sey heyle mayster Nicolay
Good morowe I se the wel for hit is day .
And shal we be lordes all oure lyf
Of al the world as Noe was ⁊and his wyf .
¶ But oo thyng I warne the full right
Be wel a vised on that ilke night .
When we ben entred in to shippes bord
That none of vs speke not a word .
Ne clepe ne crye but ben in his prayere ¶
For hit is godes heste dere .
¶ Thi wyf ⁊and thou most hange fer a twynne
For that bi tweue you shal be no synne .
No more in lokyng then ther shal in dede .
This ordynaıı̄unce is made go god the spede .
To morowe at night when alle men ben a slepe
Un to oure knedyng tubbes wol we crepe .
And sittyng there a byde godes grace
Go now thi wey I haue no lenger space .
To make of this no lenger sermonyng
Men sey thus sende the wise ⁊and sey no thyng .
Thou art so wys hit nedeth not the to teche
God saue oure lyf that I the bi seche .
¶ This sely carpynter goth forth his way
Alas ful ofte he saide ⁊and weylaway
And to his wyf he tolde his pryuete
And sheo was war ⁊and knewe hit better than he .
What al this queynte cas was forto seye
But natheles sheo fared as sheo wolde dye .
¶ And seide a las go forth thi wey a non
Helpe vs to skape or we ben dede vchon .
I am thi trewe wedded wyf
Go dere spouse ⁊and helpe to saue oure lyf .
¶ Lo whiche a gret thyng is affeccyoıı̄un
Men may dye for Imagynacyoıı̄un .
So depe may impressioıı̄un be take
This sely carpynter bigynneth to quake .
Him thynketh verreyli that he may se
Noe flod walkyng as is the se .
To drenchen Alisoıı̄un his hony dere
He wepeth ⁊and weyleth ⁊and maketh sori chere .
He syketh wᵗith mony a sory swough ¶
And goth ⁊and geteth him a knedyng trough .
And after a tubbe ⁊and a kemelynne
And pryueli he sende hem to his Inne .
And hyng hem in the roof in pryuete
Wᵗith his owne hond he made ladderes thre .
To clymbe bi rynges ⁊and bi stalkes
Vn to the tubbes hongyng on the balkes .
And thei vitayled bothe trough ⁊and tubbe
Wᵗith bred ⁊and chese ⁊and good ale in a Iubbe .
Suffisyng right y nough as for a day
But or he had mad his array .
He sende his knaue ⁊and eke his wenche also
Vpon his nedes to london forto go .
And on the monday whan hit drough to night
He shit his dore wᵗith oute candell light .
And dressed al thyng as hit shulde be
And shortly vp thei clomben alle thre .
Thei sete stylle al a forlong wey
¶ Now pr nr clum seyde Nicolay .
And clum seyde Iohn ⁊and clum seyde Alisoıı̄un
This carpynter seyde his deuocyou .
And stylle he sitteth ⁊and biddeth his prayere
And waytyng of the reyne if he hit here .
¶ The dede slepe for verrey bisynesse
Fell on this carpynter right as I gesse .
Aboute courfew tyme or litel more
For traueled of his gost wᵗith slep sore .
And eft he rowteth for his hed mys lay
Doıı̄un of the ladder stalketh Nicolay .
And Alisoıı̄un sone after sheo spedde
Wᵗithoute wordes mo thei gon to bedde .
Ther as the carpynter is wont lye ¶
There was the reuell ⁊and the melodye .
And thus light Alisoıı̄un ⁊and Nicolas
In bisynesse of merthe ⁊and of solas .
Til at the belle of laudes bigan to rynge
And freres in the caunsell bi gan to synge .
This parissh clerk this amerous Absolon
That is for loue alwey so wo bi gon .
Vpon the monday was at Oseney
Wᵗith compeny him to disport ⁊and pley
And asked vpon a cas a cloysterer
Ful pryuely after Iohn the carpynter .
And he drough him a parti out of the churche
And seide I not I say him not worche .
Sethe setterday I trowe that he be went
For tymber there oure abbot hath him sent .
For he is wont for tymber to go
And dwellen at a graunge oo day or two .
Or elles he is at his hows certeyne
Wher that he be I can not sothely seyne .
¶ This Absolon full Ioly was ⁊and light
And thought now is tyme to wake al night .
For siker I say him not sterynge .
Aboute his dore seth the day bi gon to sprynge .
So mote I thryue I shall or cockes crowe
Ful pryueli knocke at his wyndowe .
That stont full lowe vpon his boures wall
To Alisoıı̄un now wol I telle all .
My loue longyng for yit shall I not mysse
That at the lest wey I shall hur mouth kysse .
Som maner comfort shal I haue parfey
Mi mouth hath icched al this longe day .
Hit is a signe of kissyng at the leste ¶
Alnyght eke I met I was at a feste .
And ther fore I wol go slep an hour or tweye
And al the night wol I walke ⁊and pleye .
When the furst cok hath crowe a non
Vp riseth this Ioly louer Absolon .
⁊and hym a raye can at the poynt deuys
But furst he cheweth greynes ⁊and lycorys .
To smelle sote or he had kempt his here
Under his tonge a trewe loue he bere .
For ther bi wente he to be gracyous
He rometh vn to the carpynteres hous .
And stylle he stondeth vnder the shappe wyndowe
Vnto his breste hit raught hit was so lowe .
And softe he coughed wᵗith a semey soıı̄un
What do ye honycombe my swete Alisoıı̄un .
Mi feyre loue my swete cynamome
Awaketh leman ⁊and speketh tome .
Wel litell thenke ye vpon my wo
Here for youre loue I swete wher I go .
No wonder is thaugh I swelte ⁊and swete
I morne as doth the lombe after the tete .
Y wis leman I haue such loue longyng
That like a turtill trewe is my mornyng .
I may ete no more than may a mayde
Go fro the wyndowe Iacke fool sheo sayde .
As helpe me god hit wol not be come bame
I loue a nother elles were I to blame .
Wel bet than the bi Iohn Absoloıı̄un
Go forth thi wey or I wol caste a stoıı̄un .
And let me slepe a twenty deuelwey
¶ Alas qd Absolon ⁊and weylea wey .
That trewe loue was euer so euel bi set ¶
Then kysse me seth hit shall be no bet .
For Ihc loue ⁊and for the loue of me
Wolt thou go thi wey ther wᵗith qd she .
Ye certes leman qd this Absolon
Then make the redy qd sheo I come anon .
¶ This Absolon a down he sette him on his knees
And seyde I am a lord in al degrees .
For after this I hope ther cometh more
Leman thi grace ⁊and sote brid thyn ore .
¶ The wyndowe sheo vn doth ⁊and that in hast
Haue y do qd sheo ⁊and that spede the fast .
Lest that oure neighbores vs a spye
This Absolon con wype his mouth full drye .
Derk was the night as eny picche or cole
And at the wyndowe sheo put out the hole .
And Absolon him fell nouther better ne wers
Wᵗith his mouth he kissed hur naked ers .
Full sauerli or he were war of this
¶ Abak he sturte ⁊and thought he had don amys .
Ful wel he wiste a woman hedde no berd
He feled a thyng al rough ⁊and longe y hered .
And seyde fy alas what haue I do
Te he qd sheo ⁊and clapped the wyndowe to .
And Absolon goth forth a sory pas
A berd a berd qd hende Nicolas .
By god this goth ful feyre ⁊and well
This sely Absolon herde euery dell
And on his lippes he con for angur byte
And to him self he seyde I shall the quyte .
He rubbeth now he froteth his lippes
Wᵗith doust wᵗithsond wᵗith cloth wᵗith chippes .
But Absolon seith full ofte alas ¶
Mi soule bi take I to sathanas .
But me were leuer than al this toıı̄un qd he
On this despyte awreken to be .
Alas qd he alas I nedde y bleynt
His hote loue was cold ⁊and al a queynt .
For fro that tyme that he had kyssed hur ers
Of paramowres he set not a kers .
For he was heled of his maladye
Ful ofte paramowres he can defye .
And wepte as a child that is y bete
¶ A softe pas he went ouer the strete .
Vn to a smyth men cleped Gerueyse
That in his forge doth smethe plough harneys .
He sharpeth share ⁊and culture bisily
This Absolon knocketh al esily .
And seyde Gerueyse ⁊and that a non
What who art thou hit am I Absolon .
¶ What Absolon for cristes swete tre
Whi ryse ye so rathe ey benedicite .
What eyleth you som gay gyrle god hit wot
Hath brought you thus on the veritot .
Bi seynt Iohn ye wite wel what I mene
This Absolon rought not a bene .
Of al his pley no word a yein he yaf
He had more taw on his dystaf .
Then Gerueyse knewe ⁊and seyde frend so dere
The hote cultour that in thi chymeney here .
Ac lene hit me I haue ther wᵗith to done
¶ I wol brynge hit a yein ful sone.
Gerueyse seyde certes were hit gold
Or in a poke nobles vntold .
Thou shuldest hem haue as I am trewe smyth ¶
Ey cristes day what wol ye do ther with .
Ther of qd Absolon be as be may
I shal wel telle the or to morowe day .
A caughte the cultur bi the colde stele
Ful softe out at the dore con he stele .
And wente vnto the carpynteres wall
He coughed furst ⁊and knocked ther wᵗith all .
Up the wyndowe right as he dude er
¶ This Alisoıı̄un onswered who is ther .
That knocketh so I warant hit is a thef
Whi nay qd he I warant my swete lef .
¶ I am thi Absolon thi swete derlyng
Of gold qd he I haue brought the a ryng .
Mi moder yaf hit me so god me saue
Ful fyn hit is ⁊and ther to wel y graue .
This wol I yeue the if thou wolt me kysse
¶ This Nicolas was risen for to pysse .
And thought he wolde amende al the Iape
He shulde cusse his ers or that he skape .
And vp the wyndowe dude he hastely
And out his ers putte he pryuely .
Ouer the buttockes to the hanche bon
And ther with spak this clerk Absolon .
Speke swete brid I not wher thou art
This Nicolas a non let fle a fart .
As gret as hit had be a thonder dynt
That wᵗith the strok he was al most blynt .
And he redy wᵗith his Iren hot
And Nicolas in the ers he smot .
Of goth the skyn an hondy brede a boute
The hote cultur brende so his toute .
And for the smert he wende forto dye ¶
As he were wod for wo he bi gan to crye .
Helpe water helpe for cristes hert
¶ This carpynter out of his slepe stert .
And herde on crye water as he were wod
And thought a las now cometh the flod .
And sette him vp wᵗith oute wordes mo
And wᵗith an ax he smot the corde a two .
And doıı̄un goth al ⁊and he fond nouther to selle
Bred ne allebut shortli doıı̄un he felle .
Vpon the flore there in swownyng he lay
Vp stert hur vp Alisoıı̄un ⁊and Nicolay .
And cryed out ⁊and a w in the strete
There neighbores bothe smale ⁊and grete .
In ronne forto gowne on this man
And in swownyng he lay pale ⁊and wan .
For in that fall broke was his arme
But stonde he most to his owne harme .
For whenne he spak a non he was bore doıı̄un
Wᵗith hende Nicolas ⁊and Alisoıı̄un .
Thei tolde euery man that he was wood
He was a gast so of Noe flod .
Thurgh fantasye ⁊and Vanyte
He had caught him knedyng tubbes thre .
And had hem honged in the rof a boue
And that he prayed for godes loue .
To sitten in the rof by company
The folk con laughe at his fantasy .
And to the rof thei loke ⁊and gape
And turned al his harme in to a Iape .
For what so this carpynter onswered
Hit was for nought no man his resoıı̄un herd .
Wᵗith othes grete he was sworen a doıı̄un ¶
Þᵗat he washolde wood in al the toıı̄un .
For euery clerk a non hulde wᵗith other
Thei seyde the man was wood ther was non other .
And euery man can laughe at that stryf
Thus swyued was the carpynteres wyf .
For his kepyng ⁊and his Ielousye
And Absolon hath kyssed hur nether eye .
And Nicolas is skalled in his toute
This tale is don god saue all the route .
(base) ¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale
(base) Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
(base) Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
(base) Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
(base) But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
(base) Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
(base) But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
(base) By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
(base) A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
(base) He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
(base) So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
(base) With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
(base) If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
(base) But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
(base) Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
(base) This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
(base) Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
(base) But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
(base) That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
(base) Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
(base) We olde men / I drede so fare we
(base) Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
(base) We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe

div.l: (base) For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
(base) To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
(base) As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
(base) Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
(base) For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
(base) Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
(base) Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
(base) Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
(base) Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
(base) Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
(base) But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
(base) And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
(base) As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
(base) Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
(base) For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
(base) Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
(base) And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
(base) Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
(base) The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
(base) The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
(base) Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
(base) With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
(base) ¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
(base) He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
(base) He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
(base) What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
(base) The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
(base) Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
(base) Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
(base) Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
(base) Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
(base) It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne

div.l: (base) ¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
(base) I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
(base) Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
(base) For leueful is / with force / force of showue
(base) This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
(base) How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
(base) Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
(base) And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
(base) Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
(base) I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
(base) He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
(base) But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke
(base) ¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
(base) AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
(base) Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
(base) Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
(base) And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
(base) A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
(base) As any pecok he was proud and gay
(base) pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
(base) And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
(base) And by his belt he baar a long panade
(base) And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
(base) A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
(base) Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
(base) A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
(base) Round was his face and camuse was his nose
