h̉er/ree bigyneth the ꝓprolog of the clerkes tale of Oxenford
SIre clerk of Oxenford oure ost sayde
Ye ryden as stille ⁊and coy as doth a mayde
Were newe spoused syttyng at a bord
This day ne herde I of youre tonge a word .
I trowe ye studye a bout som sophyme
But salomon seith euery thyng hath tyme .
¶ For goddes sake beth of better chere
Hit is no tyme to studye here .
Telle vs som mery tale bi youre fey
For what man is entred in to apley
Him nedes mot vn to the pley asent
But precheth not as freres doth in lent .
To make vs for oure synnes wepe
Ne that thi tale make vs not forto slepe .
¶ Telle vs som mery tales of aduentures ¶
Youre termes your coloures ⁊and youre figures .
Kepe hem till so be ye endyte
Hye style as when men to kynges wryte .
Speke so playne at this tyme we you prey
That we may vnderstonde what ye sey .
¶ This worthi clerk benyngly answered
Ost qd he I am vnder youre yerd .
Ye haue of vs now the gouernaunce
And therfore wol I do youre obeysaunce .
As fer as reson asketh hardely
I wol telle you a tale whiche that I .
At Padowe of a worthi clerk
As proued bi his wordes ⁊and his werk .
He is now ded ⁊and nayled in his cheste
I prey to god yeue his soule good reste .
FRaunces Petark the lauryol poete
Hight this clerk whos rethoryk swete .
Elumpned al Itayle of poetrye
As lylian dude of philosophye .
Or lawe or other part ꝑper/partyculer
But deth that nyllot suffre vs to dwelle her .
But as hit were a twynkelyng of an eye
Hem bothe han slayn ⁊and all shull we dye .
¶ But forto telle of this worthi man
That taught me tale as I furst bigan .
Isey furst he wᵗith hye style endyteth
Or he the body of his tale wryteth .
A ꝓprohem in the whiche destruyeth he
The mount ⁊and of saluce the contre .
And speketh of Appenyn the hulles hye
That ben the hulles of west lumbardye . ¶
¶ And of mount vsules as in especyal
Where as poo out of a welle smal .
Taketh his furst spryngyng ⁊and his cours
That estward ay encreseth his cours .
To Emelward to Pherard ⁊and to venyse
The whiche a long thyng were to deuyse .
And treuly as to my Iuggement
Me thynketh hit a thyng imꝑper/partynent .
Saue that he wolde conueye his matere
This is the tale as ye may here .
Here bygyneth the clerkes tale
Ther is at the west syde of Itayle
Doıı̄un at the rote veuseles the colde
A lusty playne habundent of vytaile
Wher mony a tour ⁊and toıı̄un thou mayst biholde .
That founded were in tyme of fadres olde .
And mony a nother delytable sight
And saluce this noble contre hight .
¶ A marquys whilom was in this lond
As were his worthi eldres him bi fore
And obeysaıı̄unt ay redy to his hond
Were his lyges bothe lasse ⁊and more .
Thus in delyte he lyueth ⁊and hath don yore
Bi loued ⁊and drad bi fauour ⁊and fortune
Bothe of his lordes ⁊and of his comune .
¶ Ther wᵗith he was to speken of lynage
The gentelest born of al Itayle
A feyr ꝑper/parsone strong ⁊and yong of age
And ful of honour ⁊and curtese .
Discrete y nough his contre for to gye
Saue in som thynges he was to blame
And walter was the yong childes name . ¶
¶ I blame him thus for he considered nought
In tyme comyng what mighte bi tyde
But on his lust present was al his thought
As forto hauke ⁊and honte on euerysyde
Wel nigh alle other cures let he glyde .
And eke he nolde that was worst of alle
Wedde no wyf for ought that mighte bi falle .
¶ Only that poynt his peple bar so sore
That flokmele on a day to him thei went
And on of hem that wysest was of lore
Or elles that the lord wolde to best asent .
He shulde telle hym what this peple ment .
Or elles couthe he shewe wel such matere
He to the Marquys seyde as ye shull here .
¶ O noble Marquys youre humanyte
Assureth vs ⁊and yeueth vs hardynesse
As ofte tyme as is necessyte
That we may telle you oure heuynesse .
Accepteth lord now of youre gentelnesse .
That we with pytous herte to you pleyne
And let not youre eres my voys disteyne .
¶ Al haue I not to done in this matere
More than another man hath in this place
Yet for as meche as ye my lord dere
Haue yeue me alwey fauour ⁊and grace .
I dar the bet aske of you a space .
Of audyence to shewen oure request
And ye my lord to don right as you lest .
¶ For certes lord so wel vs lyketh you
That all youre werkes ⁊and euer haue don that we
Ne couthe not oure self deuysen how
Lyuen more we might in felycyte . ¶
Saue o thyng lord If youre wille be .
That forto be a wedded man you lest
Then were youre peple in souereynte rest .
¶ Boweth youre nek vnder the blisful yok
Of souereynte ⁊and not of seruyse
Whiche that men clepen spousayle or wedlok
And thenketh lord among your thoughtes wyse .
How that oure dayes passen in sondry wyse
For thaugh we wake or wake or rome or ryde
Ay fleth the tyme hit wol naman a byde .
¶ And thaugh we in this world haue meche delyte
In crepeth age alwey as stylle as ston
And deth manaceth euery man to smyte
In euery estate for ther skapeth non .
And also certayne we knowen euerychon .
That we shull dye uncerteyn that we alle
Ben of that day that deth shall on vs falle .
¶ Accepteth thenne the trewe entent
That neuer yet refused your hest
And we wol lord yef that ye wol asent
Chese you a wyf in short tyme at the lest .
Born of the gentelest ⁊and of the mest .
Of al this lond so that hit ought to seme
Honour to god ⁊and you as fer as we can deme .
¶ Delyuere vs out of al this bisy drede
And taketh a wyf for hye godes sake
For if hit so bi fell as god for bede
That thrugh your deth your lynage shuld slake .
And a straunge successour shulde take .
Youre herytage o wo were vs then alyue
Wher fore we prey you hastly to wyue .
¶ Hur meke preyer ⁊and hur pytous chere ¶
Made the marquys to haue pyte
Ye wollen qd he myn owne peple dere
To that I neuer er thought constrayne me .
I me reioysed of my liberte .
That selden tyme is founde in maryage
There I was fre I mot be in seruage .
¶ But natheles I se your trewe entent
And trust vpon your wit ⁊and haue dōmn ay
Wher fore I wol of my fre assent
To wedde me as sone as euer I may .
But there as ye profered me to day
To chese me a wyf I you relece
And prey you of that ꝓprofre forto sece .
¶ For god hit wot that children ofte bene
Hur worthi eldres hem bi fore
Bounte cometh of god ⁊and not of the strene
Of the whiche thei ben engendred ⁊and y bore .
I truste in godes bounte ⁊and ther fore .
Mi maryage myn estate ⁊and rest
In him I bitake he may don as him lust .
¶ Let me alone in chesyng of my wyf
That charge on my bak I wol endure
But I you pray ⁊and charge vpon your lyf
That wyf that I take ye me assure .
To worshipe hur while my lyf may dure .
In word ⁊and werk bothe here ⁊and euery where
Now accepteth of me this lytell preyere .
¶ And furthermore this shull ye swere that ye
Ayens my choys shull neuer grucche ne stryue
For I shall forgo my liberte
At youre requeste so mot I thryue .
Ther as my hert is set ther wol I wyue . ¶
And but ye woll asente in suche manere
I prey you speketh no more of this matere .
¶ Wᵗith hertely will thei sweren ⁊and asenten .
To al thyng ther seyde no wight nay
Bisechyng him or that thei wenten
To graunten hem a certeyn day .
Of his spousaile as euer he may .
For yet alway the peple som what dradde
Lest that this marquys wolde no wyf wedde .
¶ He graunteth hem such a day as him lust
On whiche he wolde be wedded sykurly
And seyde he dude al this at hur request
And thei wᵗith humble entent ful buxumly .
Knelyng on hur knees full reuerently .
Him thanked all ⁊and thus thei haue ende
Of hur entent ⁊and home ayein thei wende .
¶ And here vpon vn to his his hishisofficeres
Comaundet for the feste to puruey
And to his pryuey knightes ⁊and squyeres
Such charge yaf as him lust on hem ley .
And thei to his comaundentes obey .
And vche of hem doth his diligence
To don vn to feste reuerence .
NOught fer fro that place honourable
Where this marquys shope his mariage
Ther stod a throp of sight delytable
In whiche pore folk of that vylage .
Hedde hur bestes ⁊and hur herbygage .
And of hur labour tok hur sustynaunce
After the erthe yaf hem habundaunce .
¶ Among this pore folk ther dwelled a man
Whiche was holde porest of hem alle ¶
But hye god som tyme sende can
His grace in to a lytell oxe stalle .
Ianicula men of that throp him calle .
A doughter he had feyre ynough to sight
And Grisildes this fayre mayde hight .
¶ But for to speke of vertewes beute
Then was she on the feyrest vnder sonne
For porely fostred than was she
No lycoures lust was in hur herte ronne .
Ful ofter of the welle than of the tonne .
She dronk ⁊and for she wolde vertewe plese
She knewe wel vertewe but non Idell ese .
¶ But thaugh this mayde tendre were of age
Yet in the breste of hur virgynyte
Ther was closed sad ⁊and sharp corage
And in gret reuerence ⁊and charyte .
Hur olde pore fader fostred she .
A fewe shep spynnyng on felde she kepte
She wolde not ben Idell till she slepte .
¶ And when she home com she wolde brynge
Wortes ⁊and herbes tymes ofte
Which she shradde ⁊and seth for hur lyuynge
And made hur bed ful hard ⁊and no thyng softe .
And ay she kepte hur fadres lyf on lofte .
Wᵗith euery obeisaunce ⁊and diligence
That child may to the fadres reuerence .
¶ Vpon Grisildes the pore creature
Ful ofte Marquis set his eye
As he in huntyng rod ꝑper/paraduenture
And whenne hit fel he might hur a spye .
He not wᵗith wauntone lokyng of folye .
His eyen cast on hur but in sad wyse ¶
Vpon hir chere he wolde him ofte a vyse .
¶ Cōmmendyng in his herte hur wōmmanhed
And hur vertewe passyng euery wight
Of so yong age as wel in chere as dede
For theigh the peple haue no insight .
In vertewe she considered right .
Hur bounte ⁊and disposed that he wolde
Wedden hur if euer he wedde sholde .
¶ The day of weddyng cam but no wight can
Telle what wōmman that hit sholde be
For whiche merueyle ther wondred mony a man
And seyde when thei were in hur pryueyte .
Wil not oure lord yet leue his vanyte .
Wil he not wedde alas alas the while
Whi will he him self ⁊and vs bigyle .
¶ But natheles Marquys hath don make
Of gēmmes set in gold ⁊and in inure.
Broches ⁊and rynges for Grisildes sake
And of clothyng tok he the mesure .
Of a mayden lyk of hur stature .
And eke of other ornamentes alle
That vn to such weddyng shulde fall .
¶ The tyme of vndurne that same day
Approcheth that this weddyng shulde be
And al the palys put was in aray
Bothe halle ⁊and chambres vche in hur degre .
Houses of offices stuffed wᵗith gret plente .
There maist thou se of denteyth vytayle
That may be founde as fer as lasteth Itayle .
¶ This ryal Marquys rychely arayed
Lordes ⁊and ladyes in his compenye
The whiche vn to the feste were prayed ¶
And of his retenewe the bachalarye .
Wᵗith mony a sowne of melodye .
Vn to vyllage of whiche I tolde
In this aray the right wey hath holde .
¶ Grisilde of this god wot ful Innocent
That for hur was shapen al this aray
To fecche water at the welle is went
And cometh home as sone as she may .
For wel hed she herd that ilke day .
The marquys shulde wedde ⁊and if she might
She wolde fayn haue seye som of that sight .
¶ She saide I woll wᵗith other maydenes stonde
That ben my felowes in oure dore ⁊and se
The Marquys ⁊and ther fore wol I fonde
To done at home as hit may be .
The labour whiche that longeth vn to me .
And thenne I may at leyser hur biholde
And as she wolde ouer the threxfolde .
¶ The Marquys cam ⁊and bi gan hur for to calle
And she set doıı̄un hur water pot anon
Biside the threxfolde at the oxe stalle
And doıı̄un on hur knees she felle anon .
Nought she sayde but let him alon .
And wᵗith sad contynaunce kneleth stylle
Till she had herd what was the lordes wylle .
¶ This thoughtful Marquys spak vn to this mayde
Ful sobrely ⁊and seyde in this manere
Where is youre fader Grisildes he sayde
And she wᵗith reuerence ⁊and humble chere .
And seyde lord he is al redy here .
And in she goth wᵗith oute eny lenger let
And vn to the Marquys she hur fader fet . ¶
¶ He bi the hond tok this olde man
And seyde thus when he had him asyde
Ianicula I may neuer ne can
The plesaunce of myn herte lenger hyde .
If that thou fouchesaf what so bi tyde .
Thi doughter wol I take or that I wende
As for my wyf vnto my lyues ende .
¶ Thou louest me I wot wel certeyne
And art my liege man ybore
And that at lyketh me I dar wel seyne
Hit lyketh the ⁊and specialy ther fore .
Telle me that poynt as I haue seyd bifore
If thow wolt to this pʳpos drawe
To take me as for thi sone in lawe .
¶ The sodeyne caas the man astonyed so
That red he wax ⁊and abasshed al quakyng
He stod vnnethe seyde he wordes no mo
But only thus lord qd he wyllyng .
Is as ye wol ne a yens youre lykyng .
I wol no thyng do ye beth my lord dere
Right as you lust so gouerneth this matere .
¶ Yet wol I qd this Marquys softely
That in chambre I thow ⁊and she
Haue a collacyoıı̄un ⁊and wost thou why
For I wol axe if hit hur wylle be .
To be my wyfe ⁊and reule hur after me .
And al this shall be don in thi presence
I wol not speke out of thyn audyence .
¶ And in chambre while thei were a boute
The tretys whiche ye shull after here
The peple come in to the hows wᵗith oute ¶
And wondred hem how in so honest manere .
So denteytly she kepte hur fader dere .
But only Grisildes wondre might
For neuer er say she such a sight .
¶ Ne wondre is if she be a stonyed
To se so gret a gyst come in suche a place
She was neuer to suche gystes woned
For whiche she loketh wᵗith pale face .
But shortly forth this matere forto chace
These beth the wordes that this Marquys sayde
To this benygne ⁊and verrey feythfull mayde .
¶ Grisilde he seyde ye shull wel vnderstonde
Hit liketh vnto youre fader ⁊and to me
That I you wedde ⁊and eke hit may so stonde
As I suppose that ye will that hit so be .
But this demaundes aske I furst qd he .
That seth hit shal be don in hardy wyse
Wol ye ther to asent or elles you a vyse .
¶ I sey this be redy wᵗith good herte
Till al my lust ⁊and that I frely may
As me best lust do you laughe or smerte
And neuer ye to grucche hit night ne day .
And eke when I sey ye sey not nay .
Neither bi word frounyng contynaunce
Swere this ⁊and I swere here oure allyaunce .
¶ Wondryng for this word ⁊and quakyng for drede
She seyde lord vndigne ⁊and vnworthi
I am to thilke that ye me bede
But as ye wol your self so wol I .
And here I swere neuer wyllyngly .
In word ne in thought I wol you dysobeye
For to be ded thaugh me were loth to dye . ¶
¶ This is y nough Grisilde myn qd he
And forth he goth wᵗith a noble chere
Out at the dore ⁊and after come she
And to the peple he seyde on this manere .
This is my wyf that stondeth here .
Honoureth hur ⁊and loueth hur I you pray
Who so me loueth ther is no more to say .
¶ And for that nothyng of hur olde gere
She shulte in to his house ne be lad
That wōmmen shulde spoylen hur right there
Of whiche this wōmmen were no thyng glad .
To handelen hur clothes where she was clad .
But natheles this mayden bright of hewe
Fro fot to hed thei haue clothed al newe .
¶ Hur her haue thei kemled that lay vntrussed
Ful gentely ⁊and wᵗith hur fyngres smale
A crowne on hur hed thei haue dressed
A set hur full of owches gret ⁊and smale .
Of hur aray what shulde I make a tale .
Vnnethe the peple knewe hur for hur feyrenesse
When she transmuted was in such rychesse .
¶ This Marquys hath spoused hur wᵗith a ryng
Bought for the same cause ⁊and then hur set
Vpon an hors snowe whyte ⁊and wel ambelyng
And to his palys or he lenger let .
Wᵗith Ioyefull peple ⁊and wᵗith hur lad ⁊and met .
Conueyde hur ⁊and thus the day thei spent
In reuell till the sonne can descende .
¶ And shortly this tale forth for to chace
I sey that to this newe Marquysesse
God hath such fauour sende ⁊and grace
That hit ne semed not bi lykenesse . ¶
That she was born ⁊and fed in rudenesse .
As in a cote or in an oxe stalle
But norisshed in an emperoures halle .
¶ To euery wight she waxen is so dere
And worsshipfull that folk that euer she was bere

That humble herte ⁊and glad vysage .
Not wᵗith no swellyng thought in hur corage .
Come at his heste ⁊and on hur knees sette
And reuerently ⁊and wysly she him grette .
¶ Grisilde qd he my will is vtterly
This mayde that wedded shal be to me
Receyued be to morowe as ryally
As possible is in myn hows for to be .
And eke that euery wight in his degre .
Haue his estate in syttyng ⁊and in seruyse
And bi plesaunce as I can deuyse .
¶ I haue no wōmman suffycyaunt in certayne
The chambres to a raye in ordynaunce
After my lust ⁊and ther fore wolde I fayne
That thou were al such maner of gouernuance .
Thou knowest eke of olde al my plesaunce .
Theigh thyn aray be bad ⁊and ille bi seye
Do thou thi deuer at the leste weye .
¶ Nought only lord thar I am glad qd she
To don your lust but I desyre al so
You forto serue ⁊and plese in my degre
Wᵗith oute feyntyse ⁊and shall euer mo .
Ne neuer for no wele ne for no wo
Ne shal the gost wᵗith Inne myn herte stynt ¶
To loue yow best wᵗith al my trewe entent .
¶ And wᵗith that word she bigan the hows to dight
And tables for to set ⁊and beddes make
And peyned hur to don al that she might
Prayng the chambreres for godes sake .
To hasten ⁊and faste swepe ⁊and shake :
And she the most seruysable of all
Hath euery chambre arayed ⁊and his hall .
¶ Abouten vnderne can this Erle alight
And wᵗith him brought this noble children tweye
For whiche the peple ran to se that sight
Of hur aray so rychely bi seye
And then at the erst among hem thei seye .
That walter was no fole thei him lest
To chaunge his wyf for hit was for the best .
¶ For she is feyrer thus demen all
Then was Grisilde ⁊and more tendre of age
And bitwixe hem shulde fayrer fruyt fall
And more plesaunce for hur hye lynage .
Hur brother eke was so fayr of vysage .
And hem to se the peple hath caught plesaunce
Cōmmendyng now the Marquys gouernaunce .
¶ O stormy peple vnsad ⁊and eke vntrewe
Ay vndyscrete ⁊and chaungyng as a vane
Desyryng ay in rombbyng that is
For lyke the mone ay waxe ye ⁊and wane .
Ay ful of clappyng dere y nough a Iane .
Youre dome is fals youre constance preueth
A gret fole is he that on you leueth .
¶ Thus sayde sad folk in that Cyte
When that the peple gased vp ⁊and doıı̄un
For thei were glad right for the nouelte ¶
To haue a newe lady in hur toıı̄un .
No more of this now make I mencyoıı̄un
But to Grisilde anon wol I me dresse
And telle hur constance ⁊and hur bisynesse .
¶ Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery a thyng
That to the feste was apperteynyng
Right nought abasshed was she of hur clothyng
Thaugh hit were rude ⁊and not wel syttyng .
But she wᵗith glad chere to the gate is goyng
Wᵗith other folk to grete the Marquysesse
And after that doth forth hur bisynesse .
¶ Wᵗith so glad chere his gyftes she resceyueth
And cōmnyngly euerych in his degre
That no defaute no man aperceyueth
But ay thei wondren what she mighte be .
That in so pore aray was for to se .
And couthe such honour ⁊and reuerence
And worthi men thei preyeseden hur prudence .
¶ In al this mene while she not stynt
This mayde ⁊and eke hur brother to comende
Wᵗith al hur herte wᵗith ful benygne entent
So wel that no man couthe hur pse amende .
But at the laste whan this lordes wende .
To sytten doıı̄un to mete he bi gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle .
¶ Grisilde qd he as hit were in his play
How lyketh the my wyf ⁊and hur bewte
Right wel my lord qd she in good fay
A feyrer saugh I neuer non than she
I prey to god yeue you meche ꝓprosperyte
And so I hope he wol to you sende
Plesaunce ynough vn to your lyues ende . ¶
¶ But o thyng biseche I you ⁊and warne also
That ye ne prycke wᵗith no tormentyng
This tendre mayden as ye haue don mo
For she is fostred in hur norysshyng .
More tendrely is my supposyng
She couthe not aduersite endure
As couthe a fostred creature .
¶ And when this walter say hur pacyence
Hur glad chere ⁊and no malice at all
And he so ofte hath don hur offence
And she ay sayde ⁊and constant as a wall .
Contynuyng hur pacyence ouerall .
This sturdy Marquys can herte dresse
To rewen on hur wōmmanly studefastnesse .
¶ This is ynough Grisilde myn qd he
Be now no more euel agast ne euel apayed
I haue thi feith ⁊and thyn benyngnyte
As wel as euer wōmman was asayed .
In grete estate ⁊and pore arayed
Now knowe I dere wyf your studfastnesse
An hur in armes tok ⁊and con hur cusse .
¶ And she for wonder tok of hit no kep
She herde no thyng what he to hur sayde
She ferde as she had stert out of hur slep
Till she out of hur masednesse abreyde .
Grisilde qd he bi god that for vs dyede .
Thou art my wyf ne non other I ne haue
Ne neuer had so god my soule saue .
¶ This is thi doughter whiche thou hast supposed
To be my wyf that other feythfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay dysposed
Thou bare him in thi body treuely ¶
At boleyne I haue kepte hem puely
Take hem agayn for now maist not sey
That thou hast loren non of thi children twey .
¶ And folk that other weyes han said on me
I warne hem well that I haue don this dede
For no malyce ne for no cruelte
But forto asay in the thi wōmmanhede .
And not to sle my children god for bede .
But forto kepe hem pryuely ⁊and stylle
Till I thi pʳpos knewe ⁊and al thi wylle .
¶ When she this herde adoıı̄un she falleth
For pytous Ioye ⁊and after hur swownyng
She bothe hur yonge children to hur calleth
And in hur armes pytowsly wepyng .
Embraced hem ⁊and tendrely kyssyng .
Ful lyk a moder wᵗith hur salte teres
She batheth bothe hur vysage ⁊and hur eres .
¶ O whiche a pytows sight hit is to se
Hur swownyng ⁊and hur feble voys to here
Graunt mcy lord god I thank hit you qd she
That ye haue saued me my children dere .
Now recche I neuer to be ded right here
Sethe I stonde in youre loue ⁊and in your grace
No force of deth ne whenne my spyrit pace .
¶ O tendre o dere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende studfastly
That cruel houndes or som foule vermyne
Had eten you but god of his mercy .
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath don you kept ⁊and the same stounde
Al sodenly she swappeth doıı̄un to the grounde .
¶ And in hur swowne so sadly holdeth she ¶
Hur children two when she can hem enbrace
That wᵗith gret sleighte and dyffyculte
The children from hur arme thei can race .
O many a tere o many a pytows face .
Doıı̄un ran of hem that stonden hur bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hur couthe thei abyde .
¶ Walter hur gladeth ⁊and hur sorowe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysshed out of hur traunce
And euery wight hur Ioyeth ⁊and feste maketh
Till she haue caught ayeyn hur contynaunce .
Walter doth hur so feythfull plesaunce .
That hit denteyth for to se the chere
Bitwixe hem two now thei ben met in fere .
¶ This ladyes when thei hur tyme say
Haue taken hur ⁊and in to chambre gon
And strypen hur out of hur rude aray
And in a cloth of golde that bright shon .
Wᵗith a crowne of mony a ryche ston .
Vpon hur hed thei in to the hall hur brought
And there she was honowred as she ought .
¶ Thus hath this pytows day a blessfull ende
For euery man ⁊and wōmman doth his might
This day in reuell ⁊and merthe for to spende
Till on the welkyn shon the sterres bright .
For more solempne in euery mōmnes sight .
This feste was ⁊and gretter of costage
Then was the reuell of hur mariage .
¶ Ful mony a yere in hye prosperyte
Lyuen this two in concord ⁊and in reste
And rychely the doughter maryed he
Vnto a lord on the worthyeste .
Of al Itayle ⁊and then in pes ⁊and reste .
His wyfes fader in his court he kepeth ¶
Till that the soule out of the body crepeth .
¶ His sone succedeth in his herytage
In reste ⁊and pes after his fadres day
And fortunate eke was in maryage
Al pyt he not his wyf in so gret asay .
This world is not so strong hit is no nay .
As hit han ben in olde tyme yore
And herkeneth what this auctor seith therfore .
¶ This is seyd for that wyues sholde
Folowen Grisilde as in humylyte
For hit were unportable theigh thei wolde
But for that euery wight in his degre .
Shulde be constant in aduersyte .
As was Grisilde ther fore petrak wryteth
The story whiche wᵗith his style he endyteth .
¶ For sethen a wōmman was so pacyent
Vnto a mortell man wel more we ought
Receyue al in gre that god vs sent
For grete skyles he ꝓproued that he wrought .
But he ne tempteth no man that he bought .
As seyth seynt Iame if ye his pystell rede
He preueth folke al day hit is no drede .
¶ And suffreth vs as for oure excercyse
Wᵗith sharpe scorges ⁊and aduersyte
Ful ofte to ben bete in sondry wyse
Not to knowe oure will for certeynly he .
Or we were born knewe oure frayalte .
And for oure beste is al his gouernaıı̄unce
Let vs then lyue in vertous suffysaıı̄unce .
¶ But lordes on word herkeneth or I go
Hit were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a toıı̄un . iiij . Grisildes ¶
For if thei were put to suche asayes .
The gold of hem hath now so bad alayes
Wᵗith bras that if the coyne be feyr at the eye
Hit wolde rather berste atwo than plye .
¶ For whiche her fore the wyues loue of bathe
Whos lyf ⁊and seyde god meynteyne
In hye maystry or elles were hit skathe
I wol wᵗith lusty herte fressh ⁊and grene .
Say you a song to glade you I wene .
And let vs stynt at hernest ful matere
Herkeneth my song that seith in such manere .

(base) A yong man whilom called Melibeus myghty and

(base) and betten his wif and wounded his doghter with
fyue mortal woundes in fyue sondry places

remembred hire vp on the sentence of Ouyde in his book that

(base) he is a fool

div.l: Here bygyneth the ꝓprolog of the monkes tale
Whenne ended was the tale of Mellyble
And of prudence ⁊and of hur benignyte .
Oure Ost seyde as I am feythfull man
And by the precyous Corpus Madryan .
I had leuer than a barrell ale
That good lef my wyf had herde this tale .
For she is nothyng of soche pacyence
As was this Mellybles wyf dame pᵘdence .
By godd9 bon9 when I bete my knaues
She bryngeth me grete clubbed staues .
And cryeth sle the dogges euerychon
And breketh of hem nothe bak ⁊and bon .
And yif that eny neyhbour of myne
Wille not in churche to my wyf enclyne .
Or be so hardy to hur to trespasse
When she cometh home she rampeth in my face .
And crieth fals coward a wreke thy wyf
By god9 arm9 I wol haue thy knyf .
And thou shalt haue my distaf ⁊and go spynne
Fro day to nyght ryght thus she wol bygynne .
Allas she seyth that euer I was I shape
To wedde a mylk soppe or a coward ape .
That wol be ouerlad wᵗith euery wyght
Thou darst not stond by thy wyfes ryght .
This is my lyf but yif I wol fyght
And out at the dore anon I wol me dyght .
Or ell9 I am lost but yif that I
Be like a wode lyon ful hardy .
I wot wel she wol do me sle som day
Som neyhboᵘur and then go I my way .
For I am ꝑper/parello9 wᵗith knyfe in hand
Al be hit I dar not hur with stand .
For she is byg in arm9 bi my feyth
That shal he fynde that hur mysdoeth and seyth .
But let vs passe a wey fro this matere
My lord the monke he seyth be mery of chere . .
For ye shul telle a tale trewly
Lo Rouchestre standeth here fast by .

div.l: And casten hem ful erly for to seyle
¶ But herkene how that the oo man fille in a gret ꝑper/paryle .
That oon of hem in slepyng as he lay
He met a wonder dreme agaynes the day .
Hym thought a man stode by his beddes syde
And hym cōmmaunded that he shulde abyde .
And seyde thus yif that thou to morewe wende
Thou shalt be drouned my tale is at an ende .
¶ He a woke ⁊and tolde his felow what he mette
And prayde hym in his viage for to lette .
And for that day he prayed hym forto abyde
¶ His felaw lay by his beddes syde .
And by gan to laugh ⁊and scorne hym ful fast
No dreme qd ~ he may make myn hert agast .
That I wol let to do my thynges
I set not a strawe by thy dremynges .
For sweuenes beth but vanytees ⁊and Iapes
Men dreme al wey of owles ⁊and of apes .
But sethes I se that thou wilt here abyde
And thus for slewth wilfully thi tyde .
God wot hit reweth me ⁊and haue good day
And thus he toke his leue ⁊and went his way .
And or he had half his cours I seyled
But I not why ne what myschaunce hit eyled .
But casuelly the shippes bothom al to rent
And shipp ⁊and man vnder the water went .
In syght of other shippes hym by syde

That noman shulde be recheles

That many adreme ful sore is to drede
Lo in the lyf of Seynt kenelme I rede ~
That was kenulphes son the noble kyng

A lytel or he were murdred on a day

His noryce hym expouned euery dele
His sweuen ⁊and bad hym forto kepe hym wele .
From treson but he was to bolde
And therfor lytel tale hath he tolde .
Of eny dreme so holy was his hert
By god me had leuer than my shirt .
That ye had herd this legend as haue I
Dame Pertylot I sey now trewely .
Macrobeus that wryteth this auysyon
In affryk of the worthy cyprion .
Afformeth dremes ⁊and seyth that ther ben
Warnyng of thynges that men aftʳ seen .
¶ And furthermore I pray you loketh well
The olde testament of danyell .
Yif he hyd dremes of eny vanyte
¶ Redeth eke of Ioseph ⁊and ye shul here
Whether dremes buth som tyme I sey not all
Warnyng of thynges that shul aftʳ fall .
Loke of egipt the kyng daun Pharaoo
His baker ⁊and his boteler also .
Whether they ne feld non effect in dremes
Who wol seche the acte of sondry remes .
May reden of dremes mony a wondre thyng
¶ Lo Cresus whyche was of Lyde kyng .
Met he not that he sat vpon atre
Wheche signified that he shulde an hanged be ~ ¶The nonnes preest
Lo here Adromacha Ectores wyf
That day that Ector shuld lese his lyf
She dremed on the same nyght aforn
How that the lyf of Ector shuld be lorn .
Yif thilk day he went to batayle
She warned hym but hit myght not avayle .
He went for to fyght netheles
But he was slayn of achilles .
But thilk tale is to longe to tell
And eke hit is nyght I may no lengʳ dwell .
Shortly I say as for a conclusyon
That I shal haue of this auysyon .
Of aduersite ⁊and I say furthermore
That I wol telle of laxatises nomore .
For they ben venemys I wot ryght well
I hem defye I loue hem neuer a dell .
Now let vs speke of myrthe ⁊and stynt al this
Madame Pertylot so haue I blys .
Of oo thyng god hath send me hur grace
For whan I see the bewte in yoᵘur face .
Ye ben so skarlet rede abowte yoᵘur yen
That maketh al my drede for to dyen .
¶ For als so sekʳ as Inprincipio
¶ Mulier est hominis confusio .
Madame the sentence of this latyn is
Womman is mann9 Ioye ⁊and his blys .
For whan I felde anyght yoᵘur soft syde
Al be hit that I may not on you ryde .
For that youre perche is made so narewe alas

That I defye bothe sweues ⁊and dremes

And aftʳ wol I telle of his aduenture .
¶ When the moneth in wheche the world by gan

Was complete ⁊and passed was also .

Xl . degrees ⁊and oon ⁊and more I wys
